content.description:
On the south end of

Lower Decadent - Asian Wall

, one will see a face between 2 distinct chimneys/squeeze chimneys.  This face will be split every 15 feet or so by a pair of twin horizontal cracks (ie. face for 15 feet 2 horizontal cracks, 15 more feet of face, 2 more horizontal cracks). Climb this face utilizing the cracks for protection, at the 3rd set cross right into the chimney/crack system.  Continue to the top.  Beware of gritty rock down low.
content.protection: Medium to large gear is useful with runners.

content.description: Super easy climbing following a vertical crack through many horizontal cracks and seams leads to a couple of 5.8 face moves at the top.
content.protection: A few small to medium sized pieces in the vertical crack will adequately protect the easy climbing to the upper face. The guidebook mentions "less than ideal protection," but there are now two bolts on the upper face making it very safe.
content.location: At the far right end on the west side of the Breadloaves, between Passion for a Thrashin' and Stiff Vegetables.

content.description: This route is at the *far* Southern end of the Asian wall such that there could not possibly be any routes further to climbers right.  Directly above the wooden fencepost that begins the barbed-wire (in a grassy area by site 58) are two bolts followed by a horizontal crack with good finger/small hands gear.  This is the route.  No fixed anchors at the top.  The route is short, but it's actually pretty good as a protected highball boulder problem with a slight chance of an anal-enima by fencepost.  Worth doing if you are in the area and waiting for the longer climbs to open up.
content.protection: two bolts and a .5-ish cam + anchors (2-3 inch cams).
content.location: Far Southern end of Asian wall.

content.description: A nice route with protection where you need it.  Much more enjoyable than clipping a bolt by a naturally protectable feature, which is how this route would be bolted today.  The crux is at the start and the vertically challenged could find this route PG-13 reaching the first bolt at 15 feet, not to mention considerably harder getting off the ground.  Once the petina feature is reached however, the climbing becomes much easier to the bolt.  The most enjoyable part of this route is finding the incut holds almost completely invisible from below.  Shame to the hangdogger that ticked all the holds a couple weeks ago.
content.protection: Three bolts and a chain anchor.  Bring a single rack of cams from green alien to a 2" piece.  Nice pods present themselves midway between the first two bolts.  A third clip up high rounds out the frugal but well bolted route.
content.location: This route is at the south end of the Breadloaves formation.  It faces west on the Asia wall and starts in a grassy field directly across from the firepit of campsite #58.

content.description: Just climber's right of Steppes of Central Asia, and left ofBox Lunch is this nice chimney/crack, which protects and climbs reasonably well. Rock quality is good. Given the location, I am guessing it has been previously climbed, but could not find any info. Vivien Lee and I climbed it on 6/17/20. Standard rack to #4 cam.
content.protection: Two rappel bolts on summit. Standard rack provides good protection.
content.location: On North side of formation is a stepped face, with a central vertical crack. This is "Steppes of Central Asia." To the immediate climbers right (South), is this pleasant crack, which starts briefly as a chimney.

content.description: This is good old fashioned chimney route, and is just to climbers left of Steppes of Central Asia. The rock is solid, and the climbing is good. Two rappel bolts are found on the summit, which is to the climbers right of the route.  The R rating reflects the need for very large cams (5-6 inches), if one wishes to fully protect the route. Even with two 4 inch cams, a ground fall is possible. Nevertheless, the chimney felt secure to me.
content.protection: Cams to 4-6 inches depending on security desired
content.location: Just left of Steppes of Central Asia

content.description: Line runs up the middle of the right-most face of Asian Wall, just to the left of Self Abuse.  A good top-rope as it shares anchors with Box Lunch & Self Abuse (use a directional for easiest belay)

Left side of the main buttress on the right-most face of Asian Wall.  There's one bolt, but this is basically a trad route.  Shares anchors with Just Hold Still and Self Abuse, so can be done as a top rope with directional.

climbs.name: Just for Funzies
climbs.fa: Unknown. Vivien Lee and Peter Lenz climbed it on 6/17/20

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb the right crack (as seen in photo), and belay in boulders (20-30 feet, 5.6)

Pitch 2: Climb South Ridge to main summit of Asian Wall, and belay from chains on summit.

(80 feet, 5.3)

We broke it into 2 pitches to avoid rope drag
content.protection: Bolts on summit for rappel. Bring small rack of medium to large cams for the crack. Protection marginal on ridge, but climbing is easy.
content.location: See photo. Start in the climber’s rightmost crack, as seen from campsite 58. It is on climber’s left of the fence.
